title: Nethermind becomes out of sync and takes a long time to recover after certain ForkchoiceState events
body:
**Description**
Nethermind becomes out of sync for 1~2 minutes after "Received: ForkchoiceState", causing CL disruption.

**Steps to Reproduce**
Run Nethermind EL and attach Nimbus beacon node (CL).
Review events from both clients.

**Actual behavior**
Several times a day, Nimbus complains that the EL is not in sync and skips validator duties.
In Nethermind logs, we can see a Sync was initiated and takes 1~2min to complete.

**Expected behavior**
Nethermind should remain in sync after a ForkchoiceState, or recover fast enough so that no more than one slot is missed (<12s).

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
Please provide the following information regarding your setup:
 - Operating System: Debian GNU/Linux 11(kernel 5.10.0-21-amd64)
 - Version: v1.17.3+671d60ad/linux-x64/dotnet7.0.4
 - Installation Method: GitHub Release (stable)
 - Consensus Client: Nimbus v23.3.2-6c0d75-stateofus

**Additional context**
I'm running the latest version of Nethermind on Linux (v1.17.3+671d60ad/linux-x64/dotnet7.0.4 on Debian 11) in a home staking setup. It is paired with Nimbus (v23.3.2-6c0d75-stateofus), which runs on the same machine, and has validators attached.

Several times a day, Nethermind becomes out of sync for 1~2 minutes. This causes the CL to become optimistically synced and stop performing the validator duties over that time, and results in missed attestations.

I have two identical setups on different machines, at different locations and using different internet carriers. Both showing the exact same issue, so it does not seem related with faulty hardware or network.
The second machine only serves as a hot standby and has no validator attached. It can be used to make tests if relevant for troubleshooting.

The main difference between my current Nethermind config and the default mainnet.cfg, is that i enabled Memory pruning with larger cache and persistence interval:
```
  "Pruning": {
    "CacheMb": 16384,
    "PersistenceInterval": 32768,
    "Mode": "Memory"
  }
```
(server has 6 CPU cores, 64GB RAM and 4TB NVME storage)
Otherwise, with the exception of the JsonRpc tuning needed to work with the CL client (EnabledModules, AdditionalRpcUrls and JwtSecretFile), everything is identical to the defaults.
I will try putting back the default settings for pruning on the standby node to see if it makes a difference.

I'm not an expert on Ethereum, but if i read the events correctly, Nethermind falls into this state after receiving a ForkchoiceState that refers to a block it had not received yet.
This seems to be a situation that can normally happen (the order in which messages arrive is not guaranteed), but i don't understand why it kicks the node out of sync and why it takes so much time to recover from that state.

I have already seen Geth encountering "Forkchoice requested unknown head" events, but it never missed more than 1 slot.

Everytime the issue is observed, we can observe the same pattern in Nethermind logs:
- ForkchoiceState
- Syncing... Block ... not found
- Syncing... Unknown forkchoiceState...

The issue does not happen every time a "Received: ForkchoiceState" occurs. In most cases the ForkchoiceState would refer to a block that has been previously received, and the issue does not happen.

I'm also troubled that sometimes Nethermind appears to complain that a block could not be found, but a previous event indicates that block was inserted into the cache (see events related with 0x47a03adce90f5bf09c8fbfc61e098e980f5b73ffdef9d8e6d0e0b1ff194e12f1 in the attached log).

**Logs**
Those are the events collected during an occurrence of the issue (<datadir>/logs/mainnet.logs.txt). Timestamps are CEST / UTC+2.
```
*** issue starts here: CL client reports Nethermind not in sync from this point ***
```

Can you share the make and model of your 4TB NVMe, please

Thanks for having a look. The NVMe on each server is a ADATA XPG SSD Spectrix S40G RGB 4TB M.2 PCI Express 3.0 x4 (NVMe) (https://dcs.dk/en/p/adata-xpg-ssd-spectrix-s40g-rgb-4tb-m-2-pci-express-3-0-x4-nvme-996061913). Per the specs it can handle up to 290k read/sec and 240k writes/sec, with throughput up to 3500 MBps (read) and 3000 MBps (write).
When testing with fio i could achieve random reads and write with 24k blocks at 15/20 iops.
Under normal utilization it reports 1/2k IOPS.

I would rather have suspected the Atom C3758 CPU to be the bottleneck. I will upgrade one of those machines soon to EPYC 3251, which will 3x more powerful (https://www.cpubenchmark.net/compare/3583vs3696).

Today i've been running Nethermind with Pruning in Full mode (so disabling in-memory pruning). The issue appeared only once, so removing in-memory pruning does not completely prevent it but appears to make it less frequent.

I have attached logs and grafana plots for cpu, load, ram, network and disk utilization, those remained at low levels while the issue was ongoing.
![network](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/112125401/233526944-20486776-a327-4dfd-844f-bebd2fdec0e3.png)
![cpu](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/112125401/233526948-7b809364-5884-4185-9bff-4db8ee434369.png)
![disk-iops-percent](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/112125401/233526950-53bbb6bf-0b84-4c35-bf3a-24f869f80bec.png)
![disk-throughput](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/112125401/233526951-55c17f5e-5044-4c3c-abb9-c1c0a800722a.png)
![load](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/112125401/233526955-697eb5f9-c212-4a31-b42a-faca2a08ef9d.png)
![memory](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/112125401/233526962-fd5a24e2-e776-4c49-9078-8199f0e02af8.png)
[logs.txt](https://github.com/NethermindEth/nethermind/files/11291789/logs.txt)
hey, for the very quick look. Your Pruning cache is enormous "CacheMb": 16384" I would recommend default settings or something closer to default.

The S40G 4TB model is QLC, and so occasional slowdown is expected. Since Nethermind is the most IOPS-heavy client, I'd say this is working exactly like you'd expect it to. 

See https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1B27_j9NDPU3cNlj2HKcrfpJKHkOf-Oi1DbuuQva2gT4/edit#gid=0 and also https://gist.github.com/yorickdowne/f3a3e79a573bf35767cd002cc977b038 for a crowd-sourced list of "mainstream" models.

Thanks a lot for the insights. It's pretty much confirmed it was related with the wrong CacheMb setting. After reverting back to the default, or entirely disabling Memory pruning, the issue only occurs once a day where it was about 10 times with CacheMb set to 16GiB.

Chart helped a lot tho it's a pity to learn that this NVMe is actually QLC (while same in 2TB size was TLC). I will give those back when i'm done replacing those with Kingston Renegade Fury 4TB (SFYRd/4000G) on each server. The latter performs twice as much better on my current setup than the Adata S40G.

```
fio --randrepeat=1 --ioengine=libaio --direct=1 --gtod_reduce=1 --name=test --filename=test --bs=4k --iodepth=64 --size=150G --readwrite=randrw --rwmixread=75
```
Kingston Renegade Fury 4TB (TLC): IOPS=46k read, 15k write, BW=189MB/s read, 62.9MB/s write
Adata S40G 4TB (QLC): IOPS=13.5k read, 4.5k write, BW=55MB/s read, 18MB/s write

Not sure how much the IOPS were contributing to the issue, let's see if the last loss of sync go away with the new drive.

After further investigation, it appeared that the main contributing factor was https://github.com/status-im/nimbus-eth2/pull/4831 which is now fixed.
Secondarily, the inappropriate CacheMb value was causing a slowdown making the issue appears more often.
Third, i have no evidence of IO starvation but as such issues were reported with the model of my former NVMe i will stick with the new one which has been performing well so far.
